['Kon-Tiki (Explorer) - A raft built by Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl to prove his hypothesis about ancient sea voyages across the Pacific Ocean.', 'Polynesia - The region of islands in the South Pacific, which was one destination that Heyerdahl aimed to reach with Kon-Tiki.', 'Reed (Material) - Material used in constructing the Kon-Tiki raft from balsa logs and reeds collected from Lake Titicaca.', "Balsa Logs (Construction) - Lightweight wood pieces from the balsa tree, essential components for building Heyerdahl's raft.", "Oceania (Geography) - A region that includes Polynesia among others; a part of Heyerdahl's broader explorations and theories on ancient migrations.", 'Rafting (Activity) - The act of traveling by raft, which is the activity Heyerdahl performed with Kon-Tiki.', 'Expedition (Venture) - A journey undertaken by a group for exploration or research purposes; Kon-Tiki was an expedition led by Thor Heyerdahl.', "Anthropology (Discipline) - The scientific study of human societies and cultures, which is closely related to the purpose behind Heyerdahl's voyages.", 'Maritime History (Field) - A field that studies sea travel, naval warfare, shipping routes, etc., which Kon-Tiki helped illuminate through its voyage.', "South Pacific Ocean (Location) - The body of water where Heyerdahl's Kon-Tiki expedition aimed to sail across from Peru to Polynesia.", 'Inca Civilization (Culture) - An ancient civilization in South America, whose maritime capabilities Heyerdahl hypothesized about with Kon-Tiki.', 'Raconteur (Narrator) - A person skilled at telling stories, akin to the role Thor Heyerdahl played when sharing his findings and theories post-expedition.', "Navigate (Action) - The process of planning and directing a course, which was a crucial skill for Heyerdahl's journey with Kon-Tiki.", 'Archaeology (Science) - A branch of anthropology that studies human history through the excavation of artifacts; Kon-Tiki provided valuable insights into ancient seafaring.', "Maritime Anthropologist (Profession) - A professional who combines maritime and anthropological knowledge, similar to Heyerdahl's expertise.", 'Ethnography (Study) - The systematic study of people and cultures; Heyerdahl conducted ethnographic research during his voyages with Kon-Tiki.', "Experimental Archaeology (Method) - A field where archaeologists recreate historical artifacts or practices to better understand ancient cultures, which is part of the methodology behind Kon-Tiki's construction and voyage.", 'Indigenous Peoples (Group) - The original inhabitants of a region such as Polynesia; Heyerdahl aimed to understand their maritime heritage through Kon-Tiki.', "Anthropological Theory (Concept) - A set of ideas within anthropology that guide the interpretation and understanding of human cultures, which influenced Heyerdahl's hypotheses on ancient migrations.", "Cultural Exchange (Process) - The sharing of cultural elements between societies; Kon-Tiki's voyage aimed to demonstrate how such exchanges might have occurred through maritime travel across the Pacific Ocean."]

CLUE: Floppy-eared animal, to a small child
OUTPUT: ["Bunny - A fluffy, floppy-eared rabbit often depicted in children's stories and cartoons.", 'Kitten - A young cat with soft, droopy ears ideal for cuddling by little ones.', 'Rabbit - A small mammal known for its large floppy ears that are beloved by children.', 'Guinea Pig - Also called a Cavy, this animal has short fur and adorable droopy ears.', 'Hamster - Often kept as pets in small cages with soft fur and round ears that may flop over when sleeping or relaxed.', "Chinchilla - A small rodent with silky-soft fur, its large ears often folded down by a child's gentle touch.", 'Panda - An endangered bear species known for its black and white coat and rounded ears that appear to be floppy.', 'Mouse - Small rodents with tiny, soft ears that might catch the attention of young children when they are fluffy or relaxed.', "Hedgehog - A prickly animal at first glance but known for its cute, round floppy ears when it's not self-defense mode.", 'Beagle - A breed of dog with medium size and floppy ears, often featured in children’s books as loyal companions.', 'Dachshund - Known for its long body and short legs, but also has a variety of coat colors where the ears may be soft and floppy.', 'Otter - Semi-aquatic animals with adorable furry bodies and floppy ears that are fun to pet.', 'Ferret - A small mammal known for its playful nature, often having short fluffy ears that a child may find cuddly.', 'Fox - Known for their bushy tails but can also have floppy ears when sleeping or relaxed.', 'Otterhound - A large dog breed with droopy, soft ears and an affinity for playful interactions with children.', 'Rottweiler - Although not traditionally known for floppy ears, they can have a gentle appearance when interacting with small children.', 'Duckling - Baby ducks that are fluffy in appearance and often depicted as having large, soft ears on illustrations or toys.']

['Falcon - A bird known for its powerful and piercing call, often described as singing high in pitch.', 'Nightingale - A small migratory songbird famous for its melodious and enchanting high-pitched songs during the night.', 'Sparrowhawk - A medium-sized bird of prey with a distinctive, piercing call that can be heard above other forest sounds.', 'Albatross - Large seabirds known for their long wingspan and haunting, high-pitched calls during flight or while inland on the Antarctic continent.', 'Whistler - A bird species with a thin, penetrating whistle that can be heard from considerable distances; often used to describe small birds like waxwings.', 'Blackbird - Large passerine bird known for its high-pitched song and melodious tunes during the early morning hours.', 'Nightjar - Nocturnal insectivorous bird with a distinctive, eerie call that can be heard singing at high frequencies in dense woodlands or scrubland habitats.', 'Swift - A fast-flying migratory bird known for its haunting and melodic song; often described as "singing" during flight across the skies.', 'Swallow - Small passerine birds characterized by their aerial acrobatics, with some species also producing high-pitched, chirping calls.', 'Jay - Large, intelligent bird native to North America known for its loud and piercing call that can be heard singing at high frequencies in dense woodlands.', 'Woodcock - A migratory wading bird with a distinctive, reedy peeping song; their calls often described as "barking" or "cooing," but they do sing at higher frequencies too.', "Kirtland's Warbler - An endangered species of small woodland warbler famous for its high-pitched, buzzy songs during breeding season.", 'Northern Mockingbird - A medium-sized bird native to North America with an extensive repertoire of vocalizations that can include singing at various pitches and frequencies.', 'Kookaburra (Laughing Kookaburra) - Large, terrestrial kingfisher from Australia known for its distinctive, high-pitched laughter or chuckle; sometimes described as "singing."', 'Skylark - A small passerine bird that can be found in grasslands and open areas worldwide; their songs are often described as "sweetly singing" at high pitches above the ground level.', 'Thrush (American Robin, European Blackbird) - Small, melodious birds with varied song types; some thrush species produce high-pitched, clear tunes and whistles during breeding season or territorial displays.', 'Eaglehawk/Wedge-tailed Eagle - Large predatory bird native to Australia whose call has been likened to a "whooping" sound; while not traditionally described as singing, their vocalizations can include high-pitched elements in the form of calls and screeches.', 'Harpy Eagle (American) - Another large predatory bird native to South America whose call has been compared to a "deep, resonating bark"; though not traditionally described as singing at high pitches, their vocalizations do include low-pitched elements that can be heard over considerable distances in dense rainforest habitats.']
